title: University of California, Riverside
Privacy Policy
description: Policy The University of California, Riverside is committed to ensuring the privacy and accuracy of your confidential information to the extent possible, subject to provisions of state and federal law. Other than as required by laws that guarantee public access to certain types of information, or in response to subpoenas or other legal instruments that authorize access, personally-identifiable information is not actively shared. In particular, we do not re-distribute or sell personal information collected on our web servers.

title: Terms and Conditions of Use
description: Please Read These Terms and Conditions of Use Carefully Before Using This Site By using this site and all other registered UCR web sites, referred to as "these sites", you agree to these terms of use. If you do not agree to these terms of use, please do not use this site.

title: Office of Diversity, Equity & Inclusion
Out-of-State
description: UCR believes that out-of-state students add an important and valuable depth to our campus. Our award-winning faculty will mentor you. Our diverse campus community will embrace you. And our dedicated resources will help you build your future! Sunny Southern California invites you to make the University of California, Riverside your home away from home.

title: Campus Emergency Status
Campus Tours
First Year
description: UC Riverside is ready to help you turn your passion into purpose. Our award-winning faculty will mentor you. Our diverse campus community will embrace you. And our first-year-specific resources will help you build your future!

title: Giving
ALUMNI
Staff
description: Staff members at UC Riverside take pride in working for an institution that continually creates meaningful experiences for all Highlanders — and is rising in the ranks of national prominence. UCR was ranked the fastest rising university in America by U.S. News in 2019 and in the Top 30 of institutions dedicated to the public good by Washington Monthly in 2018. We want to create something better — on our campus and beyond — and our inspiring and dedicated staff helps us do just that. Without a doubt, the work we do daily to create transformative change on local, national, and global scales could not be done without them. And just as our staff helps to build better tomorrows by supporting UCR’s mission of research, teaching, and public service, we empower them and encourage their success through our unwavering support, resources, and mentorship — and outstanding benefits. That includes being on a campus situated in an ideal locale for work-life balance: In addition to all the vibrant city of Riverside has to offer, it’s also just a short drive from exquisite mountains, desert, and the beach.

title: Transfer Admission Guarantee
description: With UC Riverside’s Transfer Admission Guarantee (TAG), California Community College students who meet certain course and GPA requirements can secure their spot at UCR!

title: UCR team creates “quantum composites” for various electrical and optical innovations
description: UCR team has shown in the laboratory the unique and practical function of newly created materials, which they called quantum composites, that may advance electrical, optical, and computer technologies.

title: Undergraduate Admissions Statement of Privacy Practices
description: TRANSPARENCY REGARDING THE USE OF YOUR PERSONAL DATA As part of our commitment to protecting your privacy, this statement is designed to provide you with information regarding how UC Riverside (“UCR”) Undergraduate Admissions, part of UC Office of the President, collects and processes the information you share when you use our website located at admissions.ucr.edu, and each of its associated domains (together, the “Sites”), utilize the services of ours which include providing information to prospective UCR undergraduate applicant

title: COVID-19
Campus Map
SIR Today!
description: This page will be the new launch for the My.UCR.edu log-in.

title: Beyond Brilliant
Faculty
description: Faculty at UC Riverside thrive within America’s most prestigious public university system — and on one of the most dynamic campuses in the nation. UCR was America’s fastest rising university, according to the U.S. News 2019 rankings, and placed among the top 1 percent of universities worldwide, according to the 2018-19 Center for World University Rankings.  Our faculty members educate and elevate our students, our future leaders, while simultaneously creating visionary solutions and conducting path-breaking research of their own to address the greatest challenges facing our community and world. We make sure they have the resources, support, and stimulation they need to persevere. Among our distinguished faculty are two Nobel Prize winners, and 13 members of the National Academies of Science and Medicine. In fact, we are one of fewer than 20 public U.S. universities to boast multiple Nobel Prize winners on our faculty.  Every day, our diverse faculty bring an entrepreneurial spirit to education, showcasing what a public university is capable of in the 21st century. Through their interdisciplinary mindsets and shared commitment to collaborative inquiry, they are effecting the kind of transformative change that proves no barriers are too great at UCR.

title: Current Students
description: At UC Riverside students of every background and ambition, from first-generation college-goers to dedicated graduate researchers, are encouraged to dream big — and achieve their dreams.  Our students make our campus community a great place to live, learn, and grow — sharing their ideas, identities, and sense of what’s possible to help propel us forward in the dynamic digital and cultural space of an increasingly interconnected world. UC Riverside offers its undergraduate students more than 80 majors, providing plenty of options to pursue the subject matter about which they are most passionate. And our drop-in tutoring and study lounges designed to accommodate a variety of learning styles, and impressive research library — one of the largest in the nation — ensure our students have everything they need to achieve their academic goals.

title: Frequent Asked Questions
description: Would you like to know how to get involved with UCR, want to connect with fellow Highlanders in your area, or have questions about career services or membership–here’s a list of our most frequently asked questions. If you do not find the answer to your question listed within our FAQs, please contact us at 951-827-2586 or ucralum@ucr.edu.

title: Forced water-use cuts made California more waterwise

title: About UCR Alumni Association
description: Mission The UCR Alumni Association (UCRAA) serves to preserve and promote the relationships between UCR and all its alumni. Through its various services and programs, the Association represents alumni and assists the University in its quest for excellence.

title: Notable Alumni
description: 40 Under 40, UCR Launches Search for Innovative, Early-Career Alumni UCR's top-ranking education has given rise to a community of Highlander Alumni with exceptional career success, well-deserved accolades, and extraordinary achievements. The university has developed this new alumni recognition program to celebrate bold, industry-leading individuals working to change the world. The inaugural list will feature 40 of our exceptional alumni under the age of 40 and will be included in a special feature in the UCR Magazine issue for spring 2022.

title: Boozing while breastfeeding impacts health of newborns
description: Studies have shown that consuming alcohol during pregnancy can alter the brain and behavioral development of gestating offspring. Currently, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention advises against maternal alcohol consumption during pregnancy and state that there is no known safe level of consumption. What are the consequences, however, of mothers consuming alcohol while breastfeeding? A research team at the University of California, Riverside, performed a mouse study to find out.

title: Earth might be experiencing 7th mass extinction, not 6th

title: How giant-faced owls snag voles hidden in snow
description: Great gray owls’ physical features, especially parts of their wings and face, help them correct for sonic distortions caused by snow, enabling them to find moving food with astonishing accuracy, according to a new UC Riverside study.

title: Tiniest Ever Ancient Seawater Pockets Revealed
description: The surprising discovery of seawater sealed in what is now North America for 390 million years opens up a new avenue for understanding how oceans change and adapt with changing climate.

title: Post-lockdown auto emissions can’t hide in the grass
description: University of California scientists have a new way to demonstrate which neighborhoods are most affected by air pollution from vehicle emissions. Their technique could help ensure people most affected by pollution will benefit from efforts to reduce it.

title: Decoding the secret language of photosynthesis
description: For decades, scientists have been stumped by the signals plants send themselves to initiate photosynthesis, the process of turning sunlight into sugars. UC Riverside researchers have now decoded those previously opaque signals.

title: Studies identify new strategies for insect control
description: Mosquitoes spread several diseases, such as malaria and dengue. In 2020 about 241 million cases of malaria occurred worldwide, with a few more million cases occurring in 2021.

title: Highlanders one win away from Men's Soccer Championship bid
description: The UC Riverside Highlanders will host the Big West Championship final on Saturday against UC Santa Barbara, with the opportunity to win their second conference title in four years.  One more win for the top-seeded Highlanders and they will earn an automatic bid into the 2022 NCAA Division I Men's Soccer Championship. UCR won its first regular season Big West conference title this year.

In early June, the campus will finally welcome graduating Highlanders to the commencement stage, where their friends, families, and fans can cheer them on as they cross the stage in their statement caps, crisp gowns, and commemorative sashes/stoles. title: University sets new enrollment record for fall 2021
description: UC Riverside has released its enrollment numbers for fall 2021, showing a record student population of 26,847. That represent a 1.6% increase from fall 2020, when 26,434 total undergraduate and graduate students were enrolled. The student population includes 40.8% low-income students and 54.7% first-generation students. Forty-one percent of students are Latino and 35.1% Asian.

title: Should Congress treat insurrectionists as the Romans did?
description: The political divide that led to the Jan. 6, 2021 insurrection on the Capitol building has been perpetuated in discourse over how to properly address the role  of legislators who may have been involved. On the Jan. 6 anniversary of the insurrection, Michele Salzman, a UC Riverside history professor, published an opinion article in Zocalo urging lawmakers to look to the Roman response to another famous attack on another capital — the fifth century sack of the city of Rome by the Visigoths.

title: Online sites fight back against blocked ads
description: UCR research finds an astonishing 52 times more anti-ad blocking than previously thought

title: UC Riverside-led study sheds light on how IBD can develop
description: Inflammatory bowel disease, or IBD, describes Crohn’s disease and ulcerative colitis, two chronic diseases that cause inflammation in the intestines. IBD, which affects about 3 million adults in the United States, is an autoimmune disorder — a condition in which the body’s immune system attacks healthy tissues. Its symptoms include diarrhea, rectal bleeding, fatigue, weight loss, and stomach cramps.

title: Neuroscientist receives Klingenstein-Simons Fellowship Award in neuroscience

title: Pandemic hasn't deterred UCR applicants; new record is set
description: Defying pandemic-influenced predictions and national trends, the University of California, Riverside has posted record freshman applications for fall 2021.   A total of 52,263 applications were received for the fall 2021 freshman class. That represents an increase over the previous record of 49,252 for fall 2020.

title: New School of Medicine building begins construction
description: UC Riverside began construction Friday, Oct. 22 of a new School of Medicine building that will allow for growing class sizes and increasing the number of physicians trained in the underserved Inland Southern California. Campus and community leaders celebrated the start of the project at a groundbreaking ceremony at the project site south of the existing School of Medicine Education on the east side of campus.

title: For children with autism, strong bonds with teachers are key to success

title: UCR ARTS celebrates new name, purpose

title: Rare camera collection goes to Calif. Museum of Photography
“Fictive Kin” questions how we view the everyday
description: A new exhibition showcasing the photography of contemporary artists Sarah Conaway, Annette Kelm, and Kim Schoen will debut at the Culver Center of the Arts at UCR ARTSblock on Feb. 24. Much information in our daily lives is consumed through visual cues, like billboards blinking by on a highway, with little time to question authenticity. “Fictive Kin” invites viewers to consider the often-unconscious assumptions we make when looking at photos.

title: Research center receives additional Department of Energy funding
description: SHINES at UC Riverside pursues fundamental advances in energy production, storage, and use

title: Four UCR undergraduates awarded prestigious research fellowships

title: Among body shapes, pears are healthier than apples
description: Whether we like it or not, everyone accumulates fat. For women, it usually accumulates around the hips, resulting in a pear-shaped look. In men, fat tends to build up around the abdomen, creating an apple shape. As it turns out, it’s healthier to be a pear than an apple.

title: Deadline to provide vaccination proof is Aug. 16
description: Aug. 16 is the deadline for UC Riverside employees and students to upload vaccination records for fall 2021. The announcement was made in a July 16 message from Chancellor Kim A. Wilcox to the campus community.

description: Just 25 industry-standard fast charging cycles can ruin a car’s batteries

title: University of California names Michael Drake its president
description: The University of California Board of Regents unanimously named Ohio State University President Michael V. Drake, M.D., as the next president of the 10-campus UC system.  Drake, 69, is the 21st UC president, succeeding the retiring Janet Napolitano. When he assumes the helm in August, he will be the first person of color to lead the UC system. He has almost four decades experience in the UC system, first as a medical student, then as a faculty member, systemwide vice president for health affairs, and a chancellor.

title: Study explores why children remember the same things, differently
description: Children less able to manage their emotions don't remember details of frightful events

title: Perceiving support helps people cope with waiting
description: 'Worry and waiting' researcher's latest findings chart perceived support throughout periods of waiting

title: Understanding bacteria’s metabolism could improve biofuel production
description: A new study reveals how bacteria control the chemicals produced from consuming ‘food.’ The insight could lead to organisms that are more efficient at converting plants into biofuels.  The study, authored by scientists at UC Riverside and Pacific Northwest National Laboratory, has been published in the Journal of the Royal Society Interface.

title: UC Riverside registers greatest gain in U.S. News rankings
description: UC Riverside made larger gains than any university in the United States in the 2019 U.S. News & World Report Best Colleges rankings.

title: Deconstructing the indestructible ‘Luke Cage’
description: “How do you show that he’s bulletproof?” asks artist and University of California, Riverside professor John Jennings, while discussing Marvel superhero Luke Cage. “You have to shoot him. You have to have a black man during the Black Lives Matter movement shot every episode to prove that he’s bulletproof. And that’s problematic.”

UCR to host California attorney general debate
description: Primary candidates Xavier Becerra, Steven Bailey, Eric Early, and Dave Jones will convene at UCR's Culver Center on May 15

title: UC Riverside receives $7.5 million to improve large-scale networked systems
description: New Department of Defense Center of Excellence will help develop secure, fully networked command, control, and communications infrastructures

title: When disaster strikes, a search website for first responders will save lives
description: Researchers are building a tool that searches real-time text, photo, and video from many sources to help responders allocate resources

title: An interview with UCR Engineering parents
description: Parent's of graduating electrical engineering student, Frances and Ruperd Wilson Sr. reflect on their son's time at BCOE.    Q: What inspired Ruperd to attend UCR and become an Electrical Engineer?

title: Anger as an appropriate power source for social justice

title: Federal grant will help develop new stroke treatment
description: The device aims to reduce brain swelling and deliver a neuroprotective drug

title: UC Riverside reaches 77.3% for six-year graduation rate
description: UC Riverside’s six-year graduation rate — considered a leading measure of higher education excellence — has realized a new record. According to new numbers from UCR’s Office of Institutional Research, among freshmen who entered UCR in 2014, 77.3% graduated by 2020. That breaks the previous record of 76%, set last year.

title: Capturing daily life during the COVID-19 pandemic
description: UCR community’s photos, letters, and event information to be included in new library collection.

title: Inland Empire construction jobs and building activity increase
description: The latest Inland Empire Business Activity Index shows business activity in the region continuing its upward climb with the local construction industry making key contributions

title: Female presidents are held to higher standards than males
description: An analysis of presidential approval ratings reveals truths about gender biases

title: School of Public Policy names its second dean
description: Mark Long has been named dean of UC Riverside’s School of Public Policy effective Jan. 1, 2023. Long is a professor in the Evans School of Public Policy and Governance and an adjunct professor of economics at the University of Washington. He previously served as the Evans School’s associate dean for faculty affairs and associate dean for research.

title: UCR's founding School of Public Policy dean to step down after a groundbreaking run
description: As Anil Deolalikar prepared to step down this week as the founding dean of UCR’s School of Public Policy, he reflected on a groundbreaking career marked by repeatedly choosing a more challenging path. Consider when he completed his Bachelor of Arts degree in economics at Harvard University in 1977 with summa cum laude honors. The world was at his palm, but the obvious option of going to a top business or law school “never really crossed my mind,” he said.  “A lot of my friends were going into business, law, and medicine, and so they thought I was a little crazy,” he said.

title: Grant will help engineer human-like nerve tissue
description: The tissue will be used to study neurological diseases

title: Science fair aimed at Spanish-speaking families set for May 19
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif. (www.ucr.edu) — The University of California, Riverside, is hosting a free, public event on Saturday, May 19, aimed at the Spanish-speaking community. Children, teens, college students, and adults are invited to “Fiesta Familiar: Explorando La Ciencia Juntos,” presented entirely in Spanish, from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m. at the UCR Student Recreation Center.

title: Why voting is important
description: A UC Riverside student leads voter registration campaign to get classmates to the polls.

title: Graduate student’s BADASS code has astronomical benefits
description: Open-source code developed at UC Riverside is free, versatile, and easy to use

title: NOVA Wonders episode to feature UCR expert on dark matter
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif.

title: In search of dark matter
description: Particle physicist Hai-Bo Yu is an assistant professor of physics and astronomy at UC Riverside. (I. Pittalwala, UCR)

title: It’s not easy being green
description: Despite how essential plants are for life on Earth, little is known about how parts of plant cells orchestrate growth and greening. By creating mutant plants, UC Riverside researchers have uncovered a cellular communication pathway sought by scientists for decades.

title: Engineering Commencement Speakers Announced
description: David Tsai, this year’s engineering keynote speaker for the Marlan and Rosemary Bourns College of Engineering (BCOE), will follow in his father’s footsteps to inspire tomorrow’s engineers while Crysthal Alvarez, the first engineer in her family, will address her fellow graduates as the student speaker.

title: UCR ARTS awarded National Endowment for the Arts grant
description: The grant will support “Christina Fernandez: Multiple Exposures,” an exhibition opening in fall 2022.

title: 'Hypervisibility' for Black girls; 'invisibility' for Black women
description: Being a Black female might involve navigating two extremes: too little attention when you’re older, and too much of the wrong kind of attention when you’re young.

title: Resources to better understand race, racism, and policing
description: Read, watch, and listen to these 60-plus recommendations from UCR faculty and staff members

title: Different parental messages about race and ethnicity have different effects on teens’ drug use
description: Study finds promoting appreciation of ethnic-racial heritage has the potential to bolster youth’s internal resources against substance use

title: UC Riverside crests 76% for six-year graduation rate
description: In the past six years, UC Riverside's six-year graduation rate has improved by 10 percentage points

title: Border surge's cause is more complicated than COVID-19
description: The United States border has seen an increase in families — primarily men with their children — and most recently a surge in unaccompanied minors traveling north from Central America through Mexico. They are fleeing gang violence, high homicide rates, and lack of economic opportunities. In some cases, such as in Guatemala, even hunger. According to the Pew Research Center, the U.S. Border Patrol apprehended nearly 100,000 migrants in February; this after apprehensions had fallen to about 16,000 in April 2020.

title: Study documents poor mental and physical health in rural borderland community members
description: UC Riverside-led study offers vivid picture of health consequences of life events and chronic strain among foreign-born Mexicans in farm working communities

title: Turmeric compound helps grow engineered blood vessels and tissues
description: Magnetic hydrogels embedded with curcumin-coated nanoparticles promote the secretion of vascular endothelial growth factor

title: New center to address health disparities in inland Southern California
description: Five-year, $16 million grant from the National Institutes of Health will help launch Center for Health Disparities Research at UC Riverside

title: Hispanic enrollment report names UCR No. 1
description: UC Riverside stands alone among the nation’s 428 more selective public universities by exceeding its potential for the number of Hispanic students it enrolls, according to new report from the Washington, D.C.-based Urban Institute.

title: UCR’s midcentury architecture to be showcased during Modernism Week
description: Photographs, including images captured by Ansel Adams, will be featured during a free exhibition open to the public at UCR's Palm Desert Center.

title: Astronomers discover triplet of black holes on collision course
description: Unique expertise of UC Riverside scientists helped make the discovery

title: Black holes stunt growth of dwarf galaxies
description: UC Riverside astronomers find large-scale winds associated with active black holes in small galaxies suppress star formation

title: Music lecturer recognized by the National Endowment for the Arts
description: For the past 20 years Tagumpay Mendoza De Leon has been teaching Filipino rondalla music at UCR.

title: Scientists precisely measure total amount of matter in the universe
description: UC Riverside-led team’s technique relied on determining the mass of galaxy clusters

title: E-cigarette users are exposed to potentially harmful levels of metal linked to DNA damage
description: Zinc excess in the body correlates with oxidative stress

title: Study provides new insight into why galaxies stop forming stars
description: A team of UCR-led scientists get best measure yet of why star formation stopped in galaxy clusters in the early universe

title: Teaching the teachers
description: Weeklong Summer Physics Teacher Academy at UC Riverside serves a large region in Southern California

title: How the Webb telescope could ultimately help protect Earth
description: UC Riverside astrophysicist Stephen Kane breaks down some unique aspects of the James Webb Space Telescope, explains how separate Venus projects intersect, and how both might benefit Earth.

title: America’s most widely consumed oil causes genetic changes in the brain
description: New UC Riverside research shows soybean oil not only leads to obesity and diabetes, but could also affect neurological conditions like autism, Alzheimer’s disease, anxiety, and depression.

title: Everything you’ve ever wanted to know about bees
description: World Bee Day is May 20. To mark the occasion, we gathered some of UC Riverside’s top bee experts to answer questions submitted on our Instagram page. The response created, for lack of a better term, quite a buzz! We got so many questions — hundreds — that we could not answer them all on social media. For those interested in lengthier answers to some of the questions, we’ve posted many of them here, organized by topic.  Entomology

title: $1.5 million gift creates Sean and Stella Harper Endowed Scholarship Fund
description: Sean Harper is the first person to admit he wasn’t the most disciplined student when he came to UC Riverside as a biomedical sciences student four decades ago. “I was still 17 for my first few weeks at UCR,” Harper said. “I knew that I wanted to study medicine but I wasn’t the most organized or prepared student. I had a lot to learn and my time at Riverside was transformative in that regard.”

title: Research identifies possible on/off switch for plant growth
description: New research from UC Riverside identifies a protein that controls plant growth —  good news for an era in which crops can get crushed by climate change.

title: Governor’s budget proposal allocates $25 million for UCR School of Medicine
description: Additional ongoing funding would help the medical school expand enrollment

title: Author revisits lessons of prison yoga
description: The narrative surrounding the virtues of yoga instruction inside prisons is incomplete, according to a UC Riverside professor who taught yoga in prisons for several years and has written a book about the experience. “There is a false narrative, which is ‘if you improve yourself, you won’t get incarcerated,’” said Farah Godrej, an associate professor of political science. “Inside prisons, this idea of self-improvement is used in a way that’s insidious. It becomes an apparatus for telling incarcerated persons that incarceration is their own fault.”

title: Psychologist receives high honor from NAACP
description: Carolyn Murray is a professor of psychology at UC Riverside. (I. Pittalwala/UCR)

title: New model links cultural trauma with health inequalities
description: UC Riverside researchers offer new interpretation of cultural trauma

title: New property revealed in graphene could lead to better performing solar panels
description: International research team, co-led by UC Riverside physicist, shows how pure graphene efficiently converts light into electricity

title: Genetically engineered virus spins gold into beads
description: The discovery could make production of some electronic components cheaper, easier, and faster

title: Study: Children as young as 7 suffer effects of discrimination
description: A new UC Riverside study finds children are sensitive to and suffer the impacts of discrimination as young as 7 years old. Previous studies have shown children can identify racism at that age, but the study from Tuppett Yates, a UC Riverside psychology professor, and Ana Marcelo, an assistant professor of psychology at Clark University, is the first to study the impacts on children under 10 years old. The study also suggests that a strong sense of ethnic-racial identity is a significant buffer against these negative effects.

title: One-dimensional material packs a powerful punch for next generation electronics
description: The new technology has applications in nanometer-scale transistors and circuits

title: Study explores infant body position and learning
description: UC Riverside psychologist’s research provides strong evidence that infants’ motor skills directly impact the physical context of their everyday experiences

title: Thirdhand smoke can trigger skin diseases
description: UC Riverside-led clinical study advances molecular understanding of THS effects on skin

title: UCR student researcher takes smoking personally
description: You don’t want Careen Khachatoorian for a sister. Not if you smoke, you don’t. Careen’s older brother is trying to conceive a child with his partner. A typical text to her smoker-brother includes a link to a sins-of-smoking article, and reads like this: “See? Pregnant mothers have a greater chance of delivering a child with ADHD if they are exposed to smoke.” Or…  “See? Cigarette smokers don’t produce as much sperm.”

title: JUUL electronic cigarette products linked to cellular damage
description: Study by UC Riverside and Portland State University scientists finds nicotine concentrations in JUULs is dangerously high

title: State OKs $25M to double UCR medical students
description: Budget allocates ongoing funding to the medical school

title: How to eat a poison butterfly
description: In high enough concentrations, milkweed can kill a horse, or a human. To be able to eat this plant, monarchs evolved a set of unusual cellular mutations. New UC Riverside research shows the animals that prey on monarchs also evolved these same mutations.

title: Anthropologist plots new use for motion-capture technology
description: UCR bioarchaeologist Sara Becker plans to use the cutting-edge technique to document traditional labors of indigenous Andean people

title: Tobacco shops associated with crime in urban communities of color
description: UC Riverside-led study, focused on South Los Angeles, also suggests that medical marijuana dispensaries may not be closely linked to neighborhood violence

title: Study reports high level of hazardous drinking among Pacific Islander young adults in US
description: UC Riverside-led study calls for culturally tailored approaches to encourage this neglected population to seek behavioral health treatment

title: NIH grant supports new exploratory research aimed at studying Pacific Islander behavioral health
description: UC Riverside-led study will concentrate on alcohol use disorders in Pacific Islander young adults

title: For racial minority adolescents, cigarette and alcohol use tied to suicide
description: Examining more than 20 years of national data for U.S. adolescents, a research team led by Andrew Subica at the University of California, Riverside reports that adolescents have high prevalence of alcohol, cigarette, and marijuana use, and concerning rates of suicide-related thoughts and behaviors.

title: University of California and Los Alamos National Laboratory researchers receive $3.6M to secure smart campuses
description: The project, co-led by UC Riverside and UCLA, will develop a holistic framework to enhance the security, privacy, and safety of campus operation

title: How greener grids can stay lit
description: A new index to guide utility demand bidding could balance electricity distribution and lower consumer costs as California solar-panel mandate takes effect

title: COVID-19 took serious toll on Native Hawaiian/Pacific Islander mental and physical health
description: Two UC Riverside-led studies found concerning psychological and physical health problems among more than 300 NH/PIs in five US states

title: New pathway facilitates community college students joining UC Riverside medical school
description: The School of Medicine at the University of California, Riverside, has received a grant of $1.87 million to establish the Inland Empire Regional Hub for Healthcare Opportunity, or IE RHHO, which will create a pre-med pathway for local community college students.

title: Research finds pain expectation is pain reality for children
description: Research yields some advice on how to, and how not to, coach children before vaccinations

title: Psychologist to study how motor development changes infants’ learning experiences
description: John Franchak has long been interested in how learning a new motor skill, such as sitting or walking, changes how infants interact with their surroundings. He has now been awarded a grant from the National Science Foundation to pursue this research question.

title: UC psychologists devise free test for measuring intelligence
description: Raven’s Advanced Progressive Matrices, or APM, is a widely used standardized test to measure reasoning ability, often administered to undergraduate students. One drawback, however, is that the test, which has been in use for about 80 years, takes 40 to 60 minutes to complete. Another is that the test kit and answer sheets can cost hundreds of dollars, this amount increasing with more people taking the test.

title: When the world took notice
description: The course is named “Seminar in Social Psychology,” but it could be “Wednesdays with Bob.” At 85, Robert Rosenthal is in his last year teaching at UC Riverside. Distinguished Professor David Funder — who first worked with Rosenthal at Harvard University in the early 1980s — urged Rosenthal to host a semester-long brain dump. Funder is the emcee, the inquisitor. Says Rosenthal: “It’s a strange course. It’s a class about me.”

title: Special journal issue looks for new clues about old life
description: Collection edited by UCR researchers focuses on the role of rising oxygen in the birth of complex life

title: Will we be benevolent gods?
description: In his blog-turned-book, Eric Schwitzgebel tackles philosophical questions both big and (seemingly) small

title: Human skin can be damaged by exposure to thirdhand smoke and electronic cigarette spills
description: A relatively short exposure is sufficient to cause the damage, UC Riverside study finds

title: Scientists find thirdhand smoke affects cells in humans
description: UC Riverside-led study is the first to find an association between thirdhand smoke and gene expression in humans

title: Grant facilitates research on behavioral development and cognitive aging over lifespan
description: UC Riverside psychologist Chandra Reynolds will lead the five-year research project

title: Microbiome study suggests marine nematodes are not picky eaters
description: UCR research finding no relationship between nematode species and microbial profile suggests marine worms don’t have a restrictive diet

title: UCR receives its first cannabis grant
description: School of Medicine’s Nicholas DiPatrizio will lead a team tasked with assessing the impact of long-term cannabis exposure on metabolic health and disease

title: New Spectre cyberthreat evades patches
description: New speculative execution attack launches from a computer’s return stack buffer, not the branch predictor

title: New security flaw discovered in Wi-Fi routers
description: Hackers can use your wireless router to extract information, and there’s not much you can do to stop them

title: Acclaimed industry designer Scott Saltsman presents summer youth workshop in video game design
description: Gear-up for a future in technology at UCR Extension and UCR Palm Desert

title: 4 UCR graduate students win grants to do research in the natural reserves
description: Projects include the study of aquatic insect communities, bumble bees, and the impact of climate change on plants

title: New NASA-funded program to train K-12 students in STEM fields
description: Outreach components include public lectures, parent nights, and telescope viewing opportunities

title: Surprising number of exoplanets could host life
description: A new UC Riverside study shows other stars could have as many as seven Earth-like planets in the absence of a gas giant like Jupiter.

title: Study urges reconsidering therapy for Asian, Latino students
description: A new study sought to discover why Asian and Latino college students are less likely to use campus counseling services.

title: Doctors urged to reconsider controversial acne drug
description: Acne treatment including the highly effective acne medication isotretinoin should be made more readily available despite reports of its association with depression and teen suicide. That’s the implication of a study just published in the Journal of the American Academy of Dermatology. Isotretinoin has been linked to depression and suicide. But UCR researcher Misaki Natsuaki, one of the study’s authors, said severe acne itself, when left untreated, poses a serious risk for depression and anxiety.

title: Grant to physicist gives study of strongly interacting systems a boost
description: A physicist at the University of California, Riverside, has received a grant of about $523,000 from the U.S. Department of Energy to study the possible emergent behavior of “strongly interacting systems,” an important area of focus in solid-state physics.  Specifically, when the repulsive Coulomb force between electrons in a solid becomes strong, new behaviors — not easily understood from knowledge of the microscopic laws of nature — are possible.

title: Can ethics classes actually influence students’ moral behavior?
description: Philosophers and ethicists have never had scientific proof that university ethics classes affect student moral behavior — until now. A research team led by a philosopher at the University of California, Riverside, has conducted the first controlled study aiming to discover whether such a correlation exists using direct observational data rather than self-reported information.

title: Thirdhand smoke exposure linked to fabric type, heat, and humidity
description: UC Riverside-led team developed simple, rapid method to assess contaminants in household fabrics

title: You, too, can grow California’s oldest living orange variety
description: The 1000th tree okayed for growing by California’s Citrus Clonal Protection Program happens to be the oldest living orange variety in the state.

title: Controlling deadly malaria without chemicals
description: Scientists have finally found malaria’s Achilles’ heel, a neurotoxin that isn’t harmful to any living thing except Anopheles mosquitoes that spread malaria.

title: Scientists develop new method to detect oxygen on exoplanets
description: UC Riverside scientists have developed a new method for detecting oxygen in exoplanet atmospheres that may accelerate the search for life.

title: Celebrity sightings have a built-in contradiction
description: UC Riverside research helps explain a tradeoff in human behavior

title: Alzheimer's gene may impact cognition before adulthood
description: A gene linked to Alzheimer’s disease may impact cognitive health much sooner than previously realized. The APOE gene creates a protein, apolipoprotein E, which packages cholesterol and other fats to transport them through the bloodstream. There are three versions, or alleles, of APOE. One of those is the APOE4 allele, present in about 15% of the population. APOE4 carriers are up to three times more likely to develop late-onset Alzheimer’s disease, which occurs in people 65 and older.

title: Genetic background may affect adaptions to aging
description: UC Riverside-led study evaluated individual differences in DNA methylation across 10 years in two Scandinavian samples of same‐sex aging twins

title: 10 years of student wellness
description: The Well, UCR’s nonclinical health promotion center, celebrates a decade of achievements with an open house.

title: Computers, nematodes, and curiosity
description: Alejandro De Santiago Perez wants more lab experience before pursuing a doctorate in bioinformatics.

title: Some domesticated plants ignore beneficial soil microbes
description: Domestication yielded bigger crops often at the expense of plant microbiomes

title: UCR research compels response in cyber-security breach
description: Hackers look for vulnerabilities within computer systems, which are constructed for high performance to meet consumer demand. Tensions between systems administrators protecting the network, and those seeking to attack it, run high.

title: UC Riverside research compels response in cyber-security breach
description: Hackers look for vulnerabilities within computer systems, which are constructed for high performance to meet consumer demand. Tensions between systems administrators protecting the network, and those seeking to attack it, run high.

title: Out of this world: An alumna’s dream comes true
description: Brittany Seto ’16, who studied computer science at UC Riverside, interned at NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory, where a record number of UCR undergraduates are spending the summer

title: UCR Palm Desert’s MFA celebrates 10th anniversary
description: What has made this low residency, self-sustaining program successful, can be attributed to three factors: it embraces fiction genre writing, it teaches students the business aspect of writing, and is driven by student success, boasting a publication/production rate of more than 75 percent within two years of graduating.

title: Join UCR faculty and alumni at the LA Times Festival of Books
description: Attend panel discussions and book signings featuring UCR writers at the USC campus April 13-14.

title: Researcher: Tests should expect more of older adults
description: A UCR psychology researcher says the bar is too low for “functional independence” in older adults, and should be aligned with skills younger adults must conquer.  The Activities of Daily Living, or ADL, questionnaire is a standard used by healthcare professionals to decide what services older adults need to remain independent. These activities include eating and bathing. The Instrumental Activities of Daily Life, or IADL, questionnaire is a stepped-up standard that also considers basic skills such as managing money and preparing meals.

title: UCR experts discuss the J&J vaccine 'pause'
description: Even as vaccinations across the U.S. were ramping up due to the popularity and availability of the one-dose Johnson & Johnson vaccine, the CDC called a timeout due to reports of serious blood clots

title: Experts on Diversity and the Oscars
description: Diversity and the Oscars The 93rd Academy Awards are scheduled for Sunday, April 25, 2021. Experts from the University of California, Riverside are available to discuss various Academy Awards topics, including diversity, acting, gender, culture, and more.  For fast access to experts, TEXT or call the 24-hour-experts hotline at 951-312-3049, or email news@ucr.edu

title: Chemical ‘nose’ sniffs critical differences in DNA structures
description: Small changes in the structure of DNA have been implicated in breast cancer and other diseases, but they’ve been extremely difficult to detect — until now. Using what they describe as a “chemical nose,” UC Riverside chemists are able to “smell” when bits of DNA are folded in unusual ways.

title: Glass nanopore pulls DNA like spaghetti through a needle
description: The purely electrical technique captures cell-free DNA from the surface of a sample

title: Trust the power of markets
description: People trust decisions made by groups, but information markets are more accurate

title: This deep neural network fights deepfakes
description: Artificial intelligence to accurately detect altered photos is getting smarter

title: $4.8 million grant to benefit students, support community service projects
description: UCR is one of 45 colleges and universities participating in this statewide program.

title: Psychologist to explore how brain remembers precise information
description: A person’s general intelligence and ability to understand language are reliant on the brain’s ability to maintain precise information acquired over a short period of time.

title: How can you beat the COVID-19 blues? Find your flow
description: Finding the right activity could mean you experience the same well-being during the long quarantine as you would when not in quarantine, UCR research finds.

title: Exhibit reveals hidden histories behind California's citrus industry
description: A new exhibit at Riverside's California Citrus State Historic Park spotlights the overlooked architects of the region's citrus boom

title: Research identifies mechanism that helps plants fight bacterial infection
description: UC Riverside study could lead to better strategies for protecting crops from attacks by pathogens

title: Ladies’ choice: What drives faster, flashier formation of new animal species
description: Evolution is actually a Sadie Hawkins dance, as new research shows females not only determine whether male animals develop bright colors, but also how fast new species develop.

title: Project aimed at improving Latino population’s access to healthy local foods receives new funding
description: UC Riverside School of Medicine to lead engagement project in eastern Coachella Valley

title: Childhood diet and exercise creates healthier, less anxious adults
description: Exercise and a healthy diet in childhood leads to adults with bigger brains and lower levels of anxiety, according to new UC Riverside research in mice.

title: New poetry collection explores life’s questions, great and small
UCR poet wins 2018 American Book Award
description: There was a time when Rachelle Cruz, M.F.A. ’12, had all but given up on getting her poetry collection published.

title: A mother’s greatest nightmare: Susan Straight broaches school shootings
description: As of March 8, there have been 14 school shootings so far this year. Since the Feb. 14 shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., 756 copycat threats have been made targeting schools across the country.

title: Being ‘Other’ in America
description: When Nora Guerraoui receives word her father has been killed in an apparent hit-and-run, she is forced to return to the small California desert town she left behind and contend with the many memories she’s tried to forget. So sets the stage of “The Other Americans,” the latest novel by Laila Lalami published by Pantheon on March 26.

title: New movie aims to foster change in a broken system
description: “I Am Somebody’s Child,” a film based on UCR alumna Regina Louise’s memoir about growing up in foster care, premieres April 20 on Lifetime

title: ‘A closed mouth doesn’t get fed’
description: This future PepsiCo associate was raised without her parents since the age of 9. Her resiliency transformed into grit

title: Older adults: Daunted by learning a new task? Learn three
description: Learning several new things at once increases cognitive abilities in older adults, according to new research from UC Riverside. UCR psychologist Rachel Wu says one important way of staving off cognitive decline is learning new skills as a child would. That is, be a sponge: seek new skills to learn; maintain motivation as fuel; rely on encouraging mentors to guide you; thrive in an environment where the bar is set high.

title: Study provides insights into how Zika virus suppresses the host immune system
description: A research team led by scientists at the University of California, Riverside, has outlined how the Zika virus, which constituted an epidemic threat in 2016, suppresses the immune system of its host. The Zika virus, or ZIKV, spreads through mosquito bites and sexual intercourse. Currently, no approved vaccine or antivirals against ZIKV exist.

title: ‘In the Country of Women’ celebrates the ‘love of thousands’
description: Straight’s new memoir, published Aug. 6, extols the strength and resiliency of six generations of women

title: Personal stories on sexual abuse, self-worth, and academia
description: Associate Professor Victoria Reyes published her new book, “Academic Outsider: Stories of Exclusion and Hope.”

title: Quarantine Reads
description: Nineteen UCR authors offer their top picks for books to read while sheltering in place

title: Renowned mystery writer Walter Mosley to headline UC Riverside’s 43rd annual Writers Week
description: The 43rd annual Writers Week, California’s longest-running free literary event, is heading to UC Riverside, bringing a diverse array of emerging and established authors to the Inland Empire Feb. 10-14.

title: Battling bubbles: How plants protect themselves from killer fungus
description: UCR researchers show how plants fight against infections by delivering protective molecules into fungi using bubble-like exosomes

title: Mobile clinics can help address health care needs of Latino farmworkers
description: A University of California, Riverside, study that sought to determine barriers to health care among Spanish-speaking Latino farmworkers in rural communities has devised an innovative health care service delivery model that addresses many challenges these communities face.

title: UCR explores collaboration with Chinese leaders
description: This spring, a University of California, Riverside delegation traveled 6,698 miles west to Guangzhou, Guangdong, and Anhui Province in eastern China to strengthen UCR’s relationships with the region’s top educators, researchers, and government officials. Across the Pacific Ocean, Chancellor Kim A.

title: UCR explores collaboration with China’s top educations and entrepreneurs
description: This spring, a University of California, Riverside delegation traveled 6,698 miles west to Guangzhou, Guangdong, and Anhui Province in eastern China to strengthen UCR’s relationships with the region’s top educators, researchers, and government officials. Across the Pacific Ocean, Chancellor Kim A.

title: China-Russia: Any alliance is conditional, temporary
description: Related to Russia's ongoing war with Ukraine, China is fielding as many requests for aid from Russia as it's receiving threats from the West about what will happen if it provides that aid. We asked two UC Riverside China experts to provide perspective about the likelihood of all-in Chinese aid to Russia.

title: Tiny tomatoes could mean big profits for urban agriculture
description: Grants support continued development of tomatoes for vertical farming

title: China response is less visible, not less dangerous
description: In wake of a renewed COVID-19 lockdown, Chinese citizens protested openly in the streets the past several days. It's a rare display in China, where civil unrest is historically greeted with harsh government recriminations. We asked UCR professors Perry Link and Rich Carpiano to weigh in. Link co-translated The Tiananmen Papers, related to the 1989 democracy protests. In response to his role in the translation, since 1996 he has been blacklisted by China.

title: Celebrating a decade of support for UCR Guardian Scholars
description: A decade ago, Tuppett Yates, a professor of psychology at the University of California, Riverside, launched the Guardian Scholars Program in the hopes of creating a support system for students who grew up in foster care.

title: UCR faculty, staff, and alumni will be at the LA Times Festival of Books
description: This year’s Los Angeles Times Festival of Books includes a UC Riverside star-studded lineup.  Nineteen UCR faculty, staff, and alumni will be participating in this annual literary event that takes place at the University of Southern California. More than 550 authors, poets, artists, chefs, celebrities, and musicians will gather on April 23-24. See full details: LA Times Festival of Books.

title: Pandemic gun-buying binge crosses party lines
description: A fear for health and safety has driven a record number of American gun sales

title: Gun control legislation is popular; why won't it pass?
description: The routine has been too familiar for too many years. A school shooting or mass shooting event occurs and stirs the American consciousness for a moment. But a week or two passes and talk of gun-control legislation fades. The issue goes into hibernation until the next mass shooting event. In 2018, an opinion article by UCR political science Professor Ben Bishin was published in The Washington Post. It was Bishin's attempt to explain why the cycle keeps repeating itself, and who's to blame.

title: Committee for accurate Inland Empire census count marks formal launch
description: When it comes to the 2020 census, every person counts; here’s why

title: Staying on beat
description: Irvin Rosales balances school, two jobs, and a music-industry internship.

title: Microchips can permanently link patients with clinical samples
description: Project to embed patient data directly in biological samples receives Gates Foundation funding

title: Musical sensor shows bad medicine plays false note
description: Inspired by a musical instrument, the simple sensor can be constructed from common materials and used to detect adulterated or counterfeit drugs

title: Let them eat rocks
description: UC Riverside is leading an effort that could help ensure food security and improve the worst effects of climate change — by studying rock-eating bacteria and fungi.

title: Seeing through food and drug fakes and frauds
description: “Chronoprints” can identify a sample from a video taken as it reacts to disturbance

title: Simple new testing method aims to improve time-release drugs
description: Glass tuning-fork-shaped tubing gives accurate, continuous measurements of drug dissolution

title: How UCR’s Low-Residency MFA program uses remote teaching to its advantage
description: The program’s faculty members and students offer advice for transitioning to online classes due to coronavirus

title: Can I mix those chemicals? There’s an app for that!
description: New technology can find the safest way to store and dispose of reactive chemicals

title: Movement for census awareness swells in Inland Empire
description: In a two-county region at risk of an undercount, grassroots momentum has grown to ensure participation in the 2020 census

title: UC Riverside to host 42nd-annual Writers Week
description: Writers Week, California’s longest-running free literary event, will return to the University of California, Riverside, for its 42nd installment Feb. 4-5 and Feb. 11-16, 2019, featuring 22 writers across the two-week span.

title: Confronting loss and loneliness in “If You Have to Go”
description: Loneliness, while inherently isolating, is also a universal experience. This dichotomy lies at the heart of poet Katie Ford’s newest collection, “If You Have to Go.” Dominated by a crown of 39 sonnets — each linked by the repetition of the last line of a poem as the first line of the next — the book unfolds as a dreamlike narrative loosely threaded together by one solitary, longing voice.

title: Sandra Cisneros, Linda Hogan, and Ishmael Reed to be honored during Writers Week
description: The free festival, in its 45th year, will be held virtually.

title: Authors, schedule announced for 45th Writers Week
description: The February 2022 festival will be virtual. Lifetime Achievement Awards and Costo Medals will be presented to literary giants Sandra Cisneros, Linda Hogan, and Ishmael Reed.

title: New economic outlook optimistic but warns of ‘wild cards’ that could send things spiraling
description: A second outbreak will have even worse damage

title: Research links anti-immigrant prejudice to mortality risk
description: When it comes to mortality, U.S.-born individuals of immigrant descent fare much worse than their foreign-born counterparts — but why?

title: Astronauts might soon grow SPACE tomatoes
description: Grant to UC Riverside could help put tiny tomato plants on the International Space Station

title: Expert: NATO has a workaround to naval blockade
description: NATO member countries have walked a line in the months since Russia invaded Ukraine: Supporting Ukraine short of triggering large-scale war with Russia. That line may soon become more difficult to navigate, with Russia now threatening a member of NATO. We asked UCR political scientist and NATO expert Kelechi Kalu to assess Russia's current calculus in Ukraine.

title: UCR plant cell biologist elected to National Academy of Sciences
description: Sean Cutler becomes ninth UC Riverside faculty member elected to the prestigious academy
